Dear Patient Relations Team,

I am writing to formally complain about the conditions and treatment I experienced during my recent stay at Vancouver General Hospital. I was admitted for surgery on May 17,2024, and my subsequent experience has left me deeply concerned about the quality of care and overall patient management at your facility.

After my surgery, the last night I was moved to a hallway due to the apparent lack of available rooms. The hallways were overcrowded with beds and other sick patients, creating an environment that felt chaotic and stressful. This is far from the standard of care I expected from such a reputable institution.

While in the hallway, I did not have proper access to nurses or necessary medical support. This lack of access compromised my post-operative recovery and made me feel neglected and vulnerable during a critical time. The absence of privacy and the constant noise added to my discomfort and anxiety.

I understand that hospitals can face high demand and capacity issues, but the conditions I experienced were unacceptable and not conducive to recovery. Patients deserve a safe, quiet, and hygienic environment to heal, and the hallway situation fell drastically short of this standard.

I would like to request a detailed explanation of why this situation occurred and what measures are being taken to prevent similar experiences for other patients in the future. Additionally, I would appreciate information on how to proceed with filing a formal complaint and seeking compensation for the inadequate care I received.
Dr. Marsh and Dr. Pedro Jara provided my husband with exceptional care. ER staff were also great.  We will always be grateful to them and the staff at VGH.

"The Hospital of Death‚Äù

Several doctors at this hospital prioritize expedited death over quality of life, urging patients who wish to live to forego treatment. They withhold care that could improve comfort and prolong life.

Multiple departments exhibit unprofessionalism. A particular incident involved an ultrasound technician who prioritized death over life. When determining dehydration, she refused to drain fluids from the lungs for comfort, citing potential refilling as her reason.

Her exact words were disturbing. I warn others: avoid this hospital at all costs. The care is brutal and neglectful. If you enter, you will likely exit sicker.

A disturbing example: after caregivers assisted my family member with toileting, they left feces on the commode and floor, demonstrating appalling hygiene standards.

Furthermore, it seems that Asian patients receive preferential treatment. On my floor, they are consistently assigned private rooms, without apparent medical justification. Meanwhile, Caucasian patients are placed in shared rooms. This disparity raises concerns about potential bias and undue influence, possibly related to donation expectations.

One major issue with VGH is the lack of parking for patients that have a "Handicapped" permit.
We counted a total of 4 spots  that have handicapped parking spots which is TOTALLY inadequate considering the population that they are likely dealing with.
Staff are generally very supportive and helpful  and there are clear signs throughout the hospital however the precovid  barriers at reception and nurse stations  are a major impediments for patients with hearing disabilities and steps should be taken to improve these.

My wife‚Äôs brother in law showed signs of getting a stroke. We first brought him to Richmond Hospital Emergency Care, and then after initial treatment, he was immediately (within 20 to 30 minutes) transported through ambulance to Vancouver General Hospital(VGH). Great responses and excellent cares from the staffs at both facilities. Upon arrival at VGH, a team medical staffs were ready. He was immediately brought to the CT scan machine, and the medical staffs subsequently were diagnosing and analyzing the scan images. Within 15 minutes or so, Dr. Yep (not sure if correct spelling) came out and informed us that my wife‚Äôs brother in law had an artery narrowing in his head. Shortly after, Dr. Aakef came to explain that the proper treatment would be to first attempting to suck out the blockage materials, and if not effective, then a stent insertion. Upon approvals of his wife and adult children, he was immediately brought to the operating room. Everything went well. The neuro-surgeons who performed the operation were Dr. Lily Zhou, Dr. Haw, Dr. Aakef, and Dr. Meng. He was recovering well and was discharged from the hospital 2 1/2 days afterwards.
Our deep appreciations to the hospital staffs at both VGH and Richmond Hospital.  Thanks to the promptness and expertise of the medical staffs at both hospitals, my wife‚Äôs brother in law fully recovered from his stroke.

I went to the ER with obvious symptoms of a vestibular migraine (though I didn't know it at the time because I haven't been to med school). However, instead of being properly diagnosed, I was placed in the psychiatric ward and diagnosed with bipolar schizophrenia disorder. I was terrified but knew enough to realize that this diagnosis was incorrect, as I have no family history of psychiatric disorders. Additionally, only 1-2% of the general population in my country has such a disease, making the diagnosis even more unlikely.

I found the situation completely nonsensical and outrageous. Having been in BC, Canada for less than a few years, they didn't even have enough medical history on me to make such a drastic diagnosis. Instead of receiving anti-nausea medication and treatment for my severe migraine, I was forced to stay in the psychiatric ward with genuinely mentally ill patients for weeks. It wasn't until I got a lawyer involved that I was able to remove myself from this absurd healthcare system. I never imagined that something this crazy could happen.

Following my recent surgery, I encountered severe post-operative symptoms, including chest pain, shortness of breath, and numbness in my extremities, which led to an emergency visit to Vancouver General Hospital. Despite being in critical condition with erratic heart rates ranging from 45 to 178 beats per minute, I endured a distressing 5.5-hour wait before being seen.

My experience with the staff was deeply disheartening; one attendant exhibited unprofessional behavior, openly mocking my condition and showing a complete disregard for my discomfort. The emergency physician dismissed my symptoms, suggesting I was feigning them, and seemed perturbed that I was referred by my surgeon to a neurologist rather than his own care. This dismissal occurred despite my attempts to explain the severity of my symptoms.

Furthermore, when I was in obvious pain and distress, the response from the nursing staff was not only uncompassionate but confrontational, leaving me to endure the cold and discomfort unaided while I had lots of dressing in my belly, It was only through kindness of a cleaner that I was able to find some relief.

The lack of empathy and medical oversight I experienced at VGH was shocking. On the other hand, I have also been here on two separate occasions when I was concerned about something potentially life threatening:

Visit 1: Chest pain. I was admitted immediately, and seen by a doctor within minutes. An ECG, blood work, and chest X-ray were all done within an hour. Thankfully it was nothing serious and over a year later, I am completely fine.

Visit 2: Extreme abdominal pain in my lower right quadrant. My concern was appendicitis. I was admitted right away, and again seen by a doctor within minutes. I was scheduled for an ultrasound and the doctor explained that it shouldn't be too long of a wait, but it being an emergency room, you truly can never know for sure. It was 2 in the morning, and they had just received multiple traumas from a car crash so they asked me if I wanted to go home and they would call me as soon as they had an appointment available. I said yes. They gave me painkillers, and I received a phone call at 6 am to come back for an ultrasound. It was done right away and I had my results within 30 minutes. It was a ruptured ovarian cyst.

If you're complaining about the service and care you receive at this hospital, I'm assuming you have never been to a hospital in a third world country, and you don't understand how blessed we are to have healthcare and facilities like this. Those of you complaining about wait times, shame on you. This is a hospital that receives some of the worst traumas in the province. They work their butts off to save lives, and you're angry because you had to wait 4 hours while they saved other peoples lives and treated life-threatening illnesses instead of writing you a prescription? Get over yourselves. You're not the only person in pain. If you want immediate service for your non-life threatening injury or illness, go to a smaller hospital.

Also, leaving a negative review or complaining to the staff that they're understaffed is ridiculous. They can't do anything about it. Complain to your premier or local MP to increase funding to these places so we can hire more people.
